Award.AwardTitle: Integral p-adic Hodge theory and its application to automorphic Galois representations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research is in the area of number theory, one of the oldest branches of mathematics, which is concerned with questions about the integers. The research described in this proposal aims to understand the properties of the integer solutions to systems of polynomials, via some analytic, algebraic, and geometric tools. Recent advances in cryptography and coding theory have depended on solutions to these problems. For instance, most cell phone calls are protected by a code based on elliptic curves over a prime, one of the primary objects of study in the PI's field.

The PI will continue his work on integral p-adic Hodge theory. The first aim is to improve the understanding of integral structures (lattices) in semi-stable p-adic Galois representations, and then use this improvement to study the reduction of these representations. As the expected consequences, certain parts of automorphic lifting theorems and Serre's conjecture will be extended to more general settings. The second aim is to study Galois representations associated to automorphic representations and certain algebraic varieties. In particular, the PI and his collaborators will focus on the Galois representations arising from modular forms of noncongruence subgroups and certain torsion representations constructed (by Scholze) from Shimura varieties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of important goals of number theory is to understand the (common)  solutions of a set of integral polynomials. There are two important invariants for the set of solutions. The first one is the symmetry of solutions. For example, the solution of x2 -3 = 0 is  √ 3 and -√ 3 and two solutions are indeed symmetric to each other. Such symmetry is encoded in so called "Galois group". On the other hand, such set of solutions can be studied by geometric property of polynomials. For example, we can compute differentials (partial derivatives) of the polynomials on the set of solutions. One of main aims of this project is to understand how the geometric property of polynomials can relate to the symmetry of solutions, i.e., Galois group. One of key strategies in this project is to fix a prime p, then we study the solutions of polynomials modulo pn , and also differentials of polynomials modulo pn  for n very large. The main result of this project shows that  the symmetry of solution of mod pn and differentials of  polynomials modulo pn  can actually recover each other, when n is large enough.        

This project benefits the eduction of mathematics. Ph.D students take a part of project to research, and complete their theses. Conferences are organized on the research of this project to train these young mathematicians to explain their research. Finally the PI also gave lectures to the general audience so that the general audience can understand the ideas (and potential applications) of this project and number theory.
